en.purpose: To apply Rome IV criteria for diagnosing functional gallbladder disorder, helping clinicians determine when to consider cholecystectomy or alternative management strategies.
en.use:
Adult patients with recurrent biliary pain in the absence of gallstones, inflammation, or obstruction.

Diagnosis requires all of the following Rome IV criteria:

Episodes of biliary pain (located in the epigastrium or right upper quadrant).

Pain lasts at least 30 minutes, occurs at variable intervals (not daily), and is severe enough to interrupt daily activities or require medical attention.

No structural abnormalities (e.g., gallstones, cholecystitis, biliary obstruction) detected on imaging.

Abnormal gallbladder function (e.g., gallbladder ejection fraction < 40% on HIDA scan).

Negative endoscopic, laboratory, and imaging findings ruling out other causes.
en.misuse:
Should not be applied to patients with evidence of organic gallbladder disease.

Not to be used in patients with extra-biliary causes of pain (e.g., peptic ulcers, pancreatitis, functional dyspepsia).
